#Text=Hasan-Ali Beg
#Text=Bestami
#Text=Hasan-Ali Beg Bestami

#Text=( fl. 18th century ) was an important Safavid official , who subsequently became one of the closest associates of Nader Shah ( r. 1736 – 1747 ) , serving as his chief assayer ( moʿayyer al-mamālek ) .
#Text=Biography

#Text=Hasan-Ali was a slave of either Armenian or Georgian origin , and had already gained a prominent position in the late Safavid era , when he entered the royal service during the reign of king Sultan Husayn ( r. 1696 – 1722 ) , and became an important official by the 1720s . [ 1 ]
#Text=In 1726 , by Tahmasp II ' s order , Hasan-Ali was sent to report on the activities on the then emerging Nader Qoli Beg ( later known as Nader Shah ) . [ 1 ]
#Text=Persuaded by Hasan-Ali , Nader became an associate to Tahmasp II as he joined him , and on the latters ' behalf , he was appointed deputy governor of Abivard . [ 1 ]
#Text=As the Encyclopedia Iranica states ; " This encounter marked the beginning of a long and close connection between Ḥasan-ʿAli and Nāder " . [ 1 ]

column1: #Text=In the early 1730s , Hasan-Ali lived in Isfahan , and functioned as a messenger between Nader and Tahmasp II , and he oversaw the fiscal affairs of Iran from there as well . [ 1 ]
#Text=He later played a role in the removal of Tahmasp II from the throne and the subsequent crowning of then still infant Abbas III in 1732 . [ 1 ]
#Text=By 1736 , when Nader was already the de facto ruler of Iran for many years , Hasan-Ali was known as one of his most trusted and principal advisors . [ 1 ]
#Text=Nader suggested to his closest intimates , after a great hunting party on the Moghan plains , that he should be proclaimed the new king ( shah ) in place of the young Abbas III . [ 2 ]
#Text=The small group of close intimates , Nader 's friends , included Tahmasp Khan Jalayer as well as Hasan-Ali . [ 2 ]
#Text=Following Nader 's suggestion , the group did not " demur " , and Hasan-Ali remained silent .

#Text=When Nader asked him why he remained silent , Hasan-Ali replied that the best thing for Nader to do would be assembling all leading men of the state , in order to receive their agreement in " a signed and sealed document of consent " . [ 2 ]

#Text=Nader approved with the proposal , and the writers of the chancellery , which included the court historian Mirza Mehdi Khan Astarabadi , were instructed with sending out orders to the military , clergy and nobility of the nation to summon at the plains . [ 2 ]
#Text=From the crowning ceremony on the Moghan at which Hasan-Ali was present , up to Nader 's death in 1747 , he was a permanent resident at the king 's camp . [ 1 ]
#Text=After Nader 's assassination in 1747 , Hasan-Ali managed to escape . [ 1 ]

#Text=This caused Nader 's long-time Jesuit doctor Bazin to form suspicious assumptions regarding Hasan-Ali , and he therefore believed that the latter had a certain involvement in the assassination plot . [ 1 ]
#Text=Following the death of Nader and the succession to the throne by his nephew Ali-Qoli , Hasan-Ali briefly served as an important advisor to the latter . [ 1 ]
#Text=Following this short occupation , he returned to Isfahan . [ 1 ]
#Text=There , it is said that Hasan-Ali allegedly " counseled Karim Khan Zand to enthrone Abu Torab Mirza as king Ismail III in 1750 " . [ 1 ]
#Text=The descendants of Hasan-Ali adopted the title of moʿayyer al-mamālek as their family name . [ 1 ]

#Text=Decades later , one of Hasan-Ali 's namesake descendants , would serve as a government official of the then ruling Qajar dynasty of Iran , during the reign of Fath-Ali Shah Qajar ( r. 1797 – 1834 ) . [ 1 ]
#Text=He married one of the latters daughters as well , around 1834 . [ 1 ]
